data.title: The Evolution of Mann: Herbie Mann and the Flute
data.meta_description: Explore millions of resources from scholarly journals, books, newspapers, videos and more, on the ProQuest Platform.
data.text:
Cary Ginell

Â©2014 Hal Leonard Books

I begin with a candid, personal declaration: this publication is enormously gratifying. Why? Because, as a child of the '60s learning to play the flute, focusing on my classical studies and listening avidly to JeanPierre Rampai, I could not escape the "hippness of Mann" as he blazed a new trail on the instrument and sparked what was to become a lifelong interest in nonclassical music. What I did not realize fully at the time was that Herbie Mann was serving not only my musical interests but those of all flutists, because his influence has been so potent and lasting that it continues to this day, long after his passing July 1, 2003. All one has to do is to ask just about anyone to name a jazz flutist, and Herbie Mann's name very likely will be first or among the first to come up. So Cary Ginell pays an important and apt tribute not only to Herbie Mann but to the flute community as a whole with a long-overdue biography of The Mann.

Herbie Mann had a long, successful musical career spanning over 50 years. So it is perhaps something of a mystery that...
